On May 7, students from Matiakoali protested in Matiakoali to demand that the town hall resumes its activities after having been closed down by protesters in March. They blocked the road between Fada NGourma and Ouagadougou and then forced their way into the town hall.
On May 6, youth barricaded the road in Kongoussi, demanding the mining company Bissa Gold to increase local youth employment.

assoc_actor_2: CRBF: Burkina Faso Red Cross; Aid Workers (Burkina Faso)
notes: On May 3, presumed Ansaroul Islam militants abducted Red Cross (Burkina Faso) employee Bayala Bernard and seized the vehicle he was travelling in near Belehede, between Djibo and Arbinda. He was freed five days later in Nassoumbou area.

actor2: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie
notes: On May 3, presumed ISGS militants attacked the gendarmerie station in Markoye. No casualties reported.

On May 2, Presumed Ansaroul Islam militants attacked and burned the housing of the school director in the village of Bafina, the assailants tied up the school director while carrying out the misdeed. Two motorbikes belonging to teachers were also seized.

Property destruction: On May 2, presumed Ansaroul Islam militants attacked the village of Guienbile, they fired in the air at the local market and headed to the Koglweogo headquarters which they set ablaze, a beverage outlet was also burnt.
On May 2, presumed Ansaroul Islam militants attempted to abduct a civilian near Nassoumbou.

actor1: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie
notes: On May 2, combined gendarmerie and army units clashed with presumed Ansaroul Islam militants after locals alerted them about an attempted abduction near Nassoumbou.

On April 30, presumed Katiba Macina militants attacked the border police station in Madouba, Kossi Province near the Mali border, no casualties recorded, although significant material damages with the station, vehicles and motorbikes burned, several motorbikes were also seized by the assailants.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims and/or Islamic State (Greater Sahara)
notes: On April 25, presumed JNIM and/or ISGS militants attacked the village of Tangounga, wounding two civilians and burning 18 huts.

On April 25, locals in the village of Boussou closed down the town hall in protest against the absence of the mayor as well as what they deemed to be external involvement in the activities of the commune, the keys to town hall was handed to the prefect of the department and the protesters also demanded the creation of a special council to run the commune.
On April 24, students in Djibo staged a protest demanding the school to reopen after being closed due to the security situation.
On April 24, presumed Ansaroul Islam militants abducted six civilians in the area of Baraboule.

assoc_actor_1: SYNTAS: The National Union of Social Action Workers
notes: On April 24, workers belonging to the union SYNTAS staged a protest at the trade union headquarters in order to voice their dissatisfaction with authorities.
On April 24, presumed Ansaroul Islam militants assassinated a village chief, his son and a Koglweogo militiaman who had left a mosque after prayer in the village of Niafo.
Non-violent activity: On April 23, the Supreme Court in Djibo, Soum Province has been closed down after court officers received threats (including death threats).

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims and/or Islamic State (Greater Sahara)
actor2: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie
notes: On April 19, presumed JNIM and/or ISGS militants attacked a gendarmerie patrol and wounded two gendarmes in the area of Foutouri, KomondjariProvince near the Niger border

Arrests: The Burkinabe army conducted operations between April 19-27 along the borders with Mali and Niger in the north and in the east (Nakortougou and Foutouri) respectively, a hundred suspects and wanted individuals arrested, IEDs neutralized and materiel seized.

assoc_actor_1: SYNTAS: The National Union of Social Action Workers
notes: On April 18, protesters of the union SYNTAS staged a 48 hours sit-in at the Baoghin administrative complex in downtown Ouagadougou.
On April 18, presumed Ansaroul Islam militants exchanges gunfire with a police patrol in the area of Bouroy (Nassoumbou), Soum Province, no casualties reported.
On April 18, presumed Ansaroul Islam militants abducted a well-known local figure in Kekenene (Koutougou), Soum Province

On April 17, youth in Hounde protested against the recruitment policy of the mining company Hounde Gold Operation, demanding more recruitment among the local population. Security forces arrested a dozen protesters.
On April 16, residents in the 3rd District of Ouagadougou protested to demand the closure of the district town hall, claiming that it was poorly managed.

On April 15, a member of the Gourmantche community was killed amid intercommunal violence in Barimagou, the Gourmantche burned about ten houses of the Fulani, resulting in the displacement of more than 200 Fulani.
On April 12, presumed Ansaroul Islam militants attacked the school in Bouro (Nassoumbou), Soum Province, one student was killed and others wounded others, a teacher was also abducted.
On April 10, presumed Ansaroul Islam militants attacked the village of Taouremba, the militants opened fire without causing any casualties.

On April 10, presumed Ansaroul Islam militants attacked the village of Tondiata, the militants opened fire without causing any casualties. The militants had earlier visited the villages of Ariel and Damba in search of councilmen who were absent.

assoc_actor_1: Labour Group (Burkina Faso); SYNTEA: Union of Water and Sanitation Workers
notes: On April 9, employees of the Ouahigouya group of the National Office of Water and Sanitation (ONEA) staged a sit-in in Ouahigouya, demanding better living and working conditions and revalorisation of the pay scale.
On April 9, unknown gunmen opened fire on a transport truck carrying passengers and merchandise in Digani, Kossi Province, without causing any casualties.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
notes: On April 9, a Burkinabe army vehicle was struck by an IED near Koutougou, Soum Province, seven soldiers were wounded including two severely. The IED attack was most likely carried out by Ansaroul Islam militants. JNIM claimed responsibility.
On April 8, presumed Ansaroul Islam militants assassinated the mayor of Koutougou outside his home just after he had left the local mosque.
On April 5, protesters marched in Ouagadougou demanding improved housing.
On April 5, presumed Ansaroul Islam militants on motorbikes abducted the municipal councillor of Gomde-Fulbe who also is the village chief of Basnere in his home village in Djibo.
Property destruction: On April 5, presumed Ansaroul Islam militants on motorbikes opened fire at the secondary school in Belehede, and also burned classrooms and a motorbike.
On April 3, unknown gunmen attacked and gunshot wounded two Dogon herders coming from Mali in the area of Dore, the gunmen also seized their herd of livestock.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims and/or Islamic State (Greater Sahara)
notes: Property destruction: On April 1, presumed JNIM and/or ISGS militants burned a timber transport truck near the forest of Kodjagabeli, area of Tangounga.
On March 30, protesters attempted to prevent the holding of municipal council meeting in Matiacoali, security forces alerted came to the scene and dispersed the protesters, several were wounded.

actor2: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims and/or Islamic State (Greater Sahara)
notes: On March 27, Burkinabe defense and security forces raided a presumed JNIM and/or ISGS militants camp near the village of Bakani in Foutouri commune, Komondjari Province not far from the Niger border, two presumed militants were reportedly wounded and arms, ammunition and other objects seized. It is believed that militants from the Islamic State in the Greater Sahara crossed the Niger border into Burkina Faso and set up the camp targeted.
On March 26, a storage containing explosives detonated at the Mobile Customs Brigade in Bobo-Dioulasso, one customs officer and a cleaning woman were killed in the blast.
On March 21, Presumed Ansaroul Islam militants abducted a councilman in the village of Lassa, Soum Province, the councilman was taken to an unknown destination.

assoc_actor_2: Government of Burkina Faso (2015-); Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-)
notes: On March 21, presumed Ansaroul Islam militants opened fire on the residence of the prefect in Oursi. He died in a second targeted attack two months later.

Formation of armed group: On March 20, the Sunni Movement of Pouytenga established an Islamist militia called Islamic Security, its creation sparked a vivid debate, and authorities responded by ordering its disbandment.

actor2: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie
notes: On March 17, an unknown gunman opened fire on a unit of customs officers in Di, Sourou Province near the Mali border. One customs officer gunshot wounded and a weapon seized, border police pursued the assailant who opened fire once again before being shot dead, according to authorities. However, local sources said that the concerned individual refused to be checked by the customs officers at the market and attacked them with a machete, wounding one customs officer severely, then seized a weapon and opened fire. The area in question from widespread racketeering and extortion activities by security forces including customs officers and local officials.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims and/or Islamic State (Greater Sahara)
actor2: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Forest Guards
notes: On 15 March, presumed JNIM and/or ISGS militants attacked a forest guard post overnight in Nassougou, Gourma Province. One ranger killed and a vehicle burned. This is the second attack in this area in less than a week

On 13 March, the Burkinabe police exchanged gunfire with two gunmen near the Sogea-Satom's offices in Karpala, Ouagadougou. One of the gunmen was arrested while the other escaped. A motorbike, an AK, a semi-automatic handgun, three filled magazines and 80 ammunition cartridges were also seized.
On March 13, the counter-terrorism task force GFAT arrested a civilian at the market in Nassoumbou who after his arrest was extrajudicially executed.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims and/or Islamic State (Greater Sahara)
notes: On March 10, the vehicle of a concessionaire was struck by an IED in the Singou natural reserve about 20km south of Tanwalbougou (approx coordinates used), no casualties were recorded but the vehicle was severely damaged.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims and/or Islamic State (Greater Sahara)
actor2: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Forest Guards
notes: On March 9, presumed JNIM and/or ISGS militants attacked and opened fire on forest guards at a forest guard post in the area of Nassougou, the assailants seized two motorbikes.
On March 9 , protesters demanding the dissolution of the municipal council in Matiacoali, forced the mayor to close down the mayor's office and hand over the keys to the protesters.

On March 9, Kouba residents went to Koubri to protest against a real estate developer who had bought land in the area, the group was prevented to enter Koubri by another group and street fighting erupted, one individual was wounded by a machete.
On March 9, a group of gunmen aboard motorbikes, presumably Ansaroul Islam militants abducted a villager in Douhoure (Koutougou).

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims and/or Islamic State (Greater Sahara)
actor2: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Forest Guards
notes: On March 7, presumed JNIM and/or ISGS militants attacked and exchanged gunfire with forest rangers in the area of Tanwalbougou, 45km east of Fada N'Gourma, Gourma Province.

On March 4, three individuals approached a checkpoint near the Presidential palace in Ouaga 2000, one aboard a motorbike attempted to force through the checkpoint manned by the presidential guard (GSPR). Two escaped while one was arrested, the latter attempted to take a weapon from one of the soldiers while detained and was shot dead.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
notes: High-profile attack in Ouagadougou simultaneously targeted the Chief of Staff Headquarters and the French Embassy. The attack was initiated by the detonation of an explosives-laden vehicle at the Chief of Staff headquarters. Militants attacked guard posts at sites with light weapons, and gunfire was reported in the capital throughout the day. In the evening, when operations to counter the attacks had ended, eight assailants were reportedly killed, four at each location. According to official sources, eight members of Burkina's defense and security were also confirmed killed and as many as 90 wounded, including a dozen severely. The casualty toll could continue to rise as the situation evolves and the dust settles. JNIM claimed responsibility.
Angry protesters stormed and closed down the mayor's office in Matiakoali, dissatisfied with how the mayor has handled the crisis surrounding grazing land in the area.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims and/or Islamic State (Greater Sahara)
notes: On 13 February, presumed JNIM and/or ISGS militants attacked a police patrol in Natiaboani, area of Pama, not far from Fada Ngourma, one policeman was killed and two others wounded.
Security Measures: Nightly curfew and traffic ban imposed in all villages in the commune of Deou, Oudalan Province, entered into force on February 9.

Students in Tikare, 25km from Kongoussi staged a sit-in, demanding the administration to organize the schoolyear in semesters instead of quarters, staff at the school were forced to lock themselves inside the offices as protection against the angry students.
Police post in Deou, Oudalan Province attacked not long ago by two unknown gunmen, one of the assailants killed according to information currently available

Another extrajudicial killing (of a youth described as suffering of mental disorder/intellectual disability) by Burkinabe security forces in hamlet not far from Baraboule, following the attack that killed two policemen in the area of Petegoli.
On February 2, protesters in Matiakoali demanded the release of 17 individuals arrested during a previous protest that turned violent, security forces dispersed the protest by firing tear gas.
Police used teargas to disperse the crowd claiming a correction of the Tapao-Boko forest's borders.
On February 1, presumed Ansaroul Islam militants assassinated a municipal councilor and a village chief in the village of Tiemboulo.

Non-violent activity: Presumed Islamists visited the primary school of Vini, Titao Dept., Loroum Province leaving behind writings on tables and walls with intimidating messages, calling on teachers to educate in Arabic in place of French or face consequences.
Two policemen killed after being ambushed between Baraboule and Petegoli, Soum province, near the Mali border

Students from Pouytenga, Sapaga and surrounding areas demonstrated to denounce the government's silence over the lack of evaluation since the start of the school year. The big crossroads of Sapaga that was blocked for 4 hours.
On January 25, students dropped out of classes and took to the streets of Kaya to protest against the educational crisis characterized by recurring strikes and sit-ins observed by teachers.

The students of the Pouytenga County High School kidnapped their headmaster. They demanded teachers of Physics and Chemistry (CP) who are lacking since the beginning of the school year. On the sidelines of protests over the crisis in the education system, LDP students raised their voice at the lack of PC teachers in their school. They locked up the headmaster in his office, for three hours, to solve the problem of the lack of teachers of PC which they thought was too long.
Unknown gunmen attacked the village of Kacham-Ouest on the Mali border in Tin Akoff department, Oudalan province. The school was burned down, an abduction also reported.

Bousse students demonstrated at the entrance of the city. Soldiers attempted to disperse the gathering shooting in the air, while students started to throw stones: a gunshot wound in the right leg for a student in the 3rd class of private high school Nephtali.

assoc_actor_1: CNSE: National Coordination of Education Unions; Teachers (Burkina Faso)
notes: Teachers in Burkina Faso demonstrated on Wednesday and have been observing a 72-hour strike since Tuesday demanding the adoption of a "status that values the education workforce and the improvement of the quality of education and training".
Primary and secondary teachers in Bam demonstrated to denounce current practices in the province that hinder the development of quality education.
Looting: a group of gunmen attacked a gold mining site near the village of Basnere, Soum Province, residents at the site were stripped of their belongings.

assoc_actor_1: CNSE: National Coordination of Education Unions; Teachers (Burkina Faso)
notes: CNSE organised a sit-in to protest against government's educational policy.

actor2: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie
notes: One assailant killed and AK seized by the gendarmes who repelled the attack in Kelbo, Soum Province two days ago, motorbike, ammo belt and mag left behind by the assailants recovered amidst ensuing search operation.

actor2: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie
notes: Unknown gunmen attacked the gendarmerie in Toeni, Sourou Province near the Mali border around 20h, no casualties or significant damages, although the assailants seized three motorbikes

notes: JNIM claimed attack no.6 in Burkina Faso by attacking a gendarmerie post/patrol in Barani (Kossi Province) Boucle du Mouhoun Region, two gendarmes killed, arms, ammunition and two motorbikes seized as spoils of war

actor2: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie
notes: A gendarme was killed in Gomboro (Kossi) and another wounded in an ambush by suspected militants. A patrol of four gendarmes fell into an ambush Sunday morning in Pe in the rural commune of Gomboro, Kossi province (Nouna). The report mentions a policeman killed, another seriously injured and a motorcycle and two weapons carried by the attackers.

actor2: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie
notes: The gendarmerie in Deou, Oudalan Province were attacked by unknown gunmen (presumably Ansaroul Islam), military reinforcements dispatched. Assailants seized a vehicle and arms, and also gendarmes gone missing following the attack in Deou.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
actor2: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie
notes: Gendarmerie station attacked overnight in Arbinda, Soum Province, station ransacked and a motorbike seized

Looting: Gunmen opened fire in the village of Damba, some 40km northeast of Djibo, Soum province and seized a motorbike, after they moved to the nearby locality of Bouro and seized 60 cattle. No reported injuries.
Looting: Gunmen opened fire in the village of Damba, some 40km northeast of Djibo, Soum province and seized a motorbike, after they moved to the nearby locality of Bouro and seized 60 cattle.

Thousands of students were seen in front of the ministry, on the morning of December 19, 2017 in Ouagadougou. Students say they protest against the authorities' silence regarding the assessments that have been submitted since November 23, 2017.

In Burkina Faso, students demonstrated in several cities across the country to demand assessments. For weeks, teachers have filed their pens in protest, their claims have not been met. The N1 national road was blocked for several hours at a hundred kilometers from Bobo Dioulasso, in the south-west of the country.

assoc_actor_1: SYNTAS: The National Union of Social Action Workers
notes: The National Union of Social Action Workers (SYNTAS) has engaged a 96 hours strike since 19 December 2017. The strike aims to denounce the contemptuous attitude and silence of their ministry and the government over their demands. Attendance at the picket line observed by the National Union of Social Action Workers (SYNTAS) is becoming more and more mobilized compared to previous protests.
Public and private students from the city of Koupela have blocked the RN4 route with bikes to protest bad condition of the education system.

A crowd of protesters made up of carriers, students and shopkeepers from the city of Kaya blocked the road for the second day through Kaya City. The demonstrators demanded the outright release of two of their convicts for denouncing mismanagement of reserves and plots in the city of Kaya.
The administrative building of the town hall of Sapone was allegedly set on fire by MPP against the current mayor.

High school students from Zorgho, the capital of Ganzourgou province, began a 72-hour strike demanding teachers and assessments. Thousands of students gathered in front of the high commission of the city to convey their message to the first person in charge of the province.

A crowd of protesters made up of carriers, students and shopkeepers from the city of Kaya set up barricades on the road through Kaya City. The demonstrators demanded the outright release of two of their convicts for denouncing mismanagement of reserves and plots in the city of Kaya.

assoc_actor_1: ANEB: National Association of Burkinabe Students
notes: Clashes between students at the Universite Ouaga I Pr Joseph Ki-Zerbo: 5 wounded.

The RN1 was blocked with barriers by students in Tita who were demonstrating to support their teachers and denounce the lack of teachers since the beginning of the year in their schools. They clashed with a joint force of police and soldiers sent to disperse them.

Property destruction: unidentified assaillants burnt down the primary school in Nganoua, about 15km northeast of Djibo, Soum Province. More than ten primary and secondary schools have also been burned since the beginning of the "Anglophone" crisis in the South West region.
Property destruction: unidentified attackers attacked the police station in Koumbri, Yatenga Province overnight, causing significant material damage. No mentioned clash nor casualties.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
notes: Military vehicle struck by IED/mine in the area of Tounte, 4 wounded. Claimed by JNIM on 26/12.

On December 1, 2017, two presumed Malian refugees at the Mentao camp were killed in Ariel while en route to the market in Boulkessi, Mali. The two were likely to have been killed in the crossfire amidst clashes raging between Ansaroul Islam and the burkinabe army, or mistaken for militants.

Property destruction: Two presumed Ansaroul Islam members opened fire in the village of Oukoulourou about 11km from Baraboule. The gunmen ransacked the home of a councilman and also visited a local notable, telling him that they would return to the village in order to get their hands on the absent councilman. No injuries reported.

Protesters erected barricades and burned tires on the road to the university in Ouagadougou, where French President Emmanuel Macron was giving a speech. Shouting slogans such as "Down with the exploitation of Africa by the West", protesters blocked vehicles and faced riot police.

Two masked gunmen aboard a motorcycle dropped a grenade in front of Paul VI Medical Center in Tampouy during the passage of a motorcade of French militaries. Three locals wounded including one severely.

Unidentified armed individuals riding three-wheeled motorbikes killed councillor Tamboura Boucari Aissama from the village of Dohoure-Rimaiba. A second attack took place in Kain in Yatenga province. A French language teacher from the high school in Kain was killed by gunmen "on motorbikes", while two other teachers were injured during the assault on their residence.
Pouytenga students organised a sit-in to ask the resumption of assessments in high schools and colleges. Stirkes were organised also on Tuesday, Thrusday and Friday.

Property destruction: The villages of Gountour-Gnegne and Gountour-Kiri visited by gunmen who seized two motorbikes and burned one belonging to ICRC veterinarians who were conducting a vaccination campaign.

assoc_actor_1: AESO: Ouagadougou High School Students' Association
notes: AESO students went on a 72-hours strike and organised a sit-in and a march.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
notes: A police patrol was attacked around the area of Nongodoum, near the Mali border. Casualties unknown. The attack was later claimed by JNIM.
Health worker assassinated overnight in the hamlet of Bougel Kadje, area of Piladi about 20km north of Djibo, Soum Province.
Protesters went to the street to demand the acceleration and a judgment in favor of General Gilbert Diendere, arrested since October 30, 2015 following the failed coup d'etat.
On November 17, 2017, around twenty Ansaroul Islam militants raided the village of Ariel, the assailants fired in the air and abducted two villagers.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
notes: The locality of Taouremba was attacked by presumed Ansaroul Islam members, 4 Koglweogos and a village councilman killed, assailants withdrew. Claimed by JNIM on November, 24st: probably a second civilian dead.
High school students who were protesting violence by Koglweogos against a fellow student beat Koglweogos in Tiebele commune. The students wanted to avenge one of their comrades.

Property destruction: Unknown gunmen burned the primary school including three motorbikes and other materiel in Gountoure Kiri, department of Deou; teachers at the school managed to hide themselves amidst the attack

Protesters blocked access to the locality by barricading the section of the national road running through the city. They demand the resignation of the mayor and the establishment of a special delegation to manage their municipality until the next elections.
Property destruction: it was reported that the village of Tounte between Koutougou and Deou, has been attacked by presumed Ansaroul Islam members, gunfire reported and school in flames.

On November 10, 2017, the Burkinabe army clashed with presumed Ansaroul Islam militants in the area of Ariel, at least four militants were killed and four soldiers wounded including one severely who later succumbed to his wounds.

actor2: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie
notes: The gendarmerie in Bourzenga, Bam Province attacked overnight by unknown gunmen, 2 motorbikes seized.

actor2: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie
notes: Clashes took place on Monday night in Yorko, a village in the municipality of Zabre. According to the same sources, the incident was between members of the self-defense group (koglweogo) and gendarmes.

Several thousand people demonstrated Saturday in Ouagadougou to demand "truth and justice" for the deaths of the 2014 popular uprising, which drove former president Blaise Compaore out of power, and the victims of the failed coup of September 2015.
After a demonstration against a construction project, protesters changed the city hall locker, preventing anyone to access it. Police recovered keys and surround the place.
Property destruction: gunfire heard in Koutougou, it appears the police station has been attacked and burned.
On October 31, 2017, a GFAT vehicle was struck by an IED near Ariel, presumably planted by Ansaroul Islam militants, three soldiers were wounded in the blast.
Property destruction: Attack in Tounte, gunshots fired near mosque, assailants burned the school.
A teacher was killed (hit with a pestle) by unknown in Gorom-Gorom.
Clashes between students of different schools when some refused to leave classrooms.

assoc_actor_1: F-SYNTER: Federation of National Unions of Workers in Education and Research; Teachers (Burkina Faso)
notes: Education workers went on a 48-hours strike to protest against bad work conditions. A march took place around the Education Ministry.
4 individuals assassinated overnight in Basnere and 1 in Djibo
4 individuals assassinated overnight in Basnere and 1 in Djibo
A BF army sub-officer and his younger brother were assassinated overnight in Gorom-Gorom.
A forbidden demonstration agains bad governance was dispersed by police: 4 people arrested.
Non-violent activity: Gunmen on motorbikes attempted to abduct the son of a councilman in Koutougou. He escaped.
The primary school in Gomde-Fulbe was burned by unknown gunmen, teachers were stripped of their belongings and locked up.
Looting: A group (reportedly 10 on 5 motorbikes) ransacked & burned 5 outlets selling beverages in Tchalel-Goumd, near Inata.
Several associations gathered in a march celebrating the "tirailleur african" and the international peace day.
Property destruction: A group of presumed Ansaroul Islam burned the primary school in Tem.

Attack reported in the locality of Belehede, 35km east of Djibo. Water and Forest Dept. station attacked: forest guard safe and a veterinarian managed to flee, the latter wounded the shoulder during the escape. 2 motorbike and weapons seized and house ransacked.
Looting: Attack reported in Tongomayel, same axis Dori-Djibo, no details regarding targets or eventual casualty toll.
Police station in Solle, Loroum Province attacked by heavily armed gunmen.
Two gunmen aboard a motorbike shot dead a man in Djibo. The individual assassinated was a local activist, in particular against terrorism and Ansaroul Islam
Civil society protesters were dispersed by police: they were protesting against the release of general Bassole
1 killed, 3 abducted and governement vehicle seized by unknown gunmen in Tin Edja, Oudalan Province.

3000 people went to the street to call for the liberation of ancient foreign Minister Djibril Bassole, involved in the 2015 coup d'etat.
Three people - a village council member, an imam and an old man - were killed in Touronata by unidentified armed men, in targeted attacks.

actor2: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie

actor1: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie

actor2: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie
notes: Convoy of fuel trucks escorted by the gendarmerie subjected to IED+gunfire attack along the Tongomayel-Inata axis. 2 dead and several wounded among security forces. 2 more died at the hospital.
GFAT (CT-unit) patrol targeted by a mine/IED around 6h this morning on the axis Djibo-Mentao, 4 soldiers severely wounded following the blast.
Heavy gunfire at the checkpoint of the refugee camp, south of Djibo. Security post burned, no casulties reported.
Communal violence between farmers and herders in Garkere leaves one dead and another severely wounded.
Armed men kidnapped and later killed a civilian from Diaodiao village.
Village chief of Tem near Nassoumbou abducted and executed by presumed Ansaroul Islam members.
Three individuals incl. Wendpoli village chief assassinated overnight in the Soum, near Mali border.
The mayor's office in Diguel, Soum attacked by presumed Ansaroul Islam members, material damages & the accountant abducted.
2 individuals abducted by unknown gunmen this morning in Kourfadji (Nassoumbou).

Movement of forces: Incursion by presumed Ansaroul Islam members who fired in the air & threatened locals in Damba
People from Sanyiri neighbourhood went to the street to protest against the murder of a policeman by a local retail trader. The main road was blocked and the murderer's store was plundered.
A thousand people went to the streets to protest against violence and terrorist attacks.
3 dead and several wounded in IED/mine blast that struck an army vehicle in the area of Inata.

Armed assault on restaurant Aziz Istanbul. 19 dead, a dozen wounded and 2 assailants killed by Burkinabe special forces' assault. Attackers were suspected to be Islamists but no individual groups have claimed responsibility yet.

Armed assault on restaurant Aziz Istanbul. 19 dead, minaly foreign citizens, a dozen wounded and 2 assailants killed by Burkinabe special forces' assault. Attackers were suspected to be Islamists but no individual groups have claimed responsibility yet.

Clashes between gold miners and land owners from the Diebougou region at at the Loto mining site, 5km from Diebougou in Bougouriba, in the south west of Burkina Faso, left one killed and 10 injured, including 3 severely. Material damage was also reported, including a truck that was burnt down.

assoc_actor_1: UCRB: Union of Burkina Truck Drivers
notes: Truck drivers blocked traffic on national road 16, at Tenkodogo, to protest the reintroduction of licence fees. Police intervened to disperse them, leading to clashes and tear gas throwing.

Populations of Goudin village set up barricades along the national road 4 (from Nioko, Bendogo and up to Fada) to protest the arrest of 6 Koglweogo leaders from their village without charge. They were chased by security forces, who also fired tear gas to disperse them. Police arrested six rioters.

A civilian was shot and killed by unknown gunmen on 30 July in unclear circumstances in Sona, Tongomayel commune of Sahel province. Authorities believe the attack to be linked to the presence of terrorist groups in the area.

A soldier shot and killed a civilian working for an oil company in Balole locality, Bingo dept, in unclear circumstances. Citizens from Balole locality erected a barricade on the road leading to the oil site the following day to protest the killing and to call for justice. Rocks were thrown when authorities came to negotiate with the rioters, but it is unclear if they hit the authorities.
A soldier shot and killed a civilian working for an oil company in Balole locality, Bingo dept, in unclear circumstances.
Another serie of assassinations by unidentified gunmen in the Soum Province, a councilman & two of his family members in Kenou, also one in Petega.
Another serie of assassinations by unidentified gunmen in the Soum Province, a councilman & two of his family members in Kenou, also one in Petega.
Dozens of people and local representatives marched in Karkuidghin in Sapone commune, Bazega province (Centre-Sud) to show their support to the Mayor of Sapone.
People set up barricades along the Ouaga-Leo-Frontiere du Ghana route protesting the raise of electricity price.

assoc_actor_1: SYNAGRH: National Union of Human Resource Managers and Public Administration
notes: SYNAGRH workers went on a 48-hours sit-in protesting negotiations' lack of results.

A series of attacks by unidentified gunmen in Ndidja, Neyba and Sibe villages of Djibo left at least 5 dead, including 2 in Ndidka and 2 in Sibe. Authorities believe the attacks were part of an internal rift between armed groups in the area. The victims were identified as members of Anseroul Islam, while the attackers are unknown

assoc_actor_1: SYNTSHA: National Union of Human and Animal Health Workers
notes: Human and animal health workers in Dedougou, Mouhoun section, led by SNYTSHA, held a sit-in on 24 and 25 July calling for better working conditions.

assoc_actor_1: SYNACIT: Independent Union of Labour Inspectors and Controllers
notes: SYNACIT organised a 48-hours sit-in protesting the material work conditions.

Report of acts of vandalism in Sapone commune, Bazega province (Centre-Sud) prior to the holding of a local administration session on 23 July, with some people setting up barricades along the main roads and destroying private properties.

assoc_actor_1: SYNAID: National Union of Tax Agents
notes: SYNAID workers organsied a four-day long sit-in protesting against the lack of implimented changes from a previous agreement. The protesters occupied a main square in the capital and there were interactions with police but no violence or arrests were mentioned. The government declared that public offices will not close.

assoc_actor_1: SYNAID: National Union of Tax Agents
notes: SYNAID workers organsied a four-day long sit-in protesting against the lack of implimented changes from a previous agreement. The protesters occupied a main square in the capital and there were interactions with police but no violence or arrests were mentioned. The government declared that public offices will not close.
A Kourfadji inhabitant was kidnapped by presumed terrorists.

The protesters occupied a main square in the capital and there were interactions with police but no violence or arrests were mentioned. The government declared that public offices will not close.

The protesters occupied a main square in the capital and there were interactions with police but no violence or arrests were mentioned. The government declared that public offices will not close.
On 17 July 2017, presumed Ansaroul Islam militants abducted a prominent goldminer in Kerboule, he was released nine months later.
Zoetgomde village people interrupted a "comunity day" going on in the Kinshasa neighbourhood to protest the expropriation and selling of their agricultural land.
Suspected jihadists opened fire on a police patrol in the Doumbala area and fled towards the Malian border.
People demonstrated to support Mayor Dominique Sourabie.
Inhabitants fought Fulani herders after cattle damaged field in Doussoula, Sourou province in north west on 11 July. One killed.
Civil society organisation organised a march protesting the motion of deposition against the Gourcy Major.
Clashes between sector 5 and sector 1 youngsters were reported: prompted by the undressing of a traditional "mask", violence erupted triggering significant material damages.

assoc_actor_2: CDP: Congress for Democracy and Progress
notes: CDP president denounced several recent acts of violence against its members in Ouagadougou, including the intrusion of armed men within the house of the former party president, who beat his mother and wounded his son; as well as the shooting at a former minister's window.
Former mutinous policemen fired in 2012 demonstrated asking for their integration.

assoc_actor_1: SYNACSAB: National Union of Civil Servants, Secretaries and Administrative Assistants of Burkina Faso
notes: A sit-in was organised by SYNACSAB to protest the bad working conditions.
SYNACSAB - public officers' Labour Union - organised a sit-in in front of High Commission building in Bam capital city asking for better work conditions.
Non-violent activity: Jafar Dicko assumed the leadership of Ansaroul Islam, Maalam Dicko supposedly dead.
The demonstration against the bad conditions of the RNo4 failed to gather a significant number of people.
People protested in front of the Prefecture asking the mayor to step back.
People went to the street and blocked traffic circulation to protest about a land issue.
A local council member and a farmer were killed by unidentified aggressors.
People asking for the liberation of a prisoner vandalised the Justice Palace.
A group of 6 unknown gunmen attacked the village of Woba-Tila near Belehede. They allegedly withdrew towards Mali.
A march for the peace was organised by the FEME.
Five people were killed by armed men in the area close to Malian border. Three were killed in Pogouwol in the Soum Depertement, while one in Petega and another in Kourou.
Five people were killed by armed men in the area close to Malian border. Three were killed in Pogouwol in the Soum Depertement, while one in Petega and another in Kourou.
Five people were killed by armed men in the area close to Malian border. Three were killed in Pogouwol in the Soum Depertement, while one in Petega and another in Kourou.

Retired policeman shot dead by "unknown gunmen": his wife was wounded by gunshot. 1 of the assailants was later killed by a group of security forces and a vigilante militia. The house of the Grand Imam of Djibo was also subjected to gunfire. Gunmen later identified as Anseroul Islam.

assoc_actor_2: Muslim Group (Burkina Faso); Former Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-)
notes: On 27 May 2017, Anseroul Islam shot and killed a retired policeman and wounded his wife and fired upon the home of the Grand Imam in Djibo (Soum, Sahel). Police forces and a communal group later clashed on the same day (coded separately).

On 27 May 2017, Anseroul Islam clashed with police forces and a Djibo communal militia in Djibo (Soum, Sahel). These clashes follow an attack in the same place this day (coded separately). 1 Anseroul Islam militant was killed in the clash.
Demonstration against the attmpted lynching of artist Adja Divine organised by Burkina Association of Artists.
In the Koyinga village of Sangha, clashes between the Moba and Yaana ethnies over a land conflict resulted in one dead, one wounded and several material damages
Civil society organisations gathered to protest agains persisting impunity of blood and economic crimes.

People from the Dabre and Zampaligre families clashed over the enthronement of the new customary chief belonging to the Zampaligre family: the two dead and five wounded belong all to the Zampaligre family.
Hundreds of people demonstrated claiming for truth and justice about Dabo Boukary assassination in 1990.
A Koglweogo Militia member killed two young people. He was later lynched by the population.
A Koglweogo Militia member killed two young people. He was later lynched by the population.

Koglweogo Militia members were beaten up by Tialgo people after an attempt to fine a local family scaled up tensions and resulted in an injury. 3 dead and several wounded, while 3 youths were abducted by Koglweogos and 5 Koglweogos detained by the Gendarmerie.
Unknown gunmen killed a village councilman and wounded another by gunfire in N'Diahoye.

actor1: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie
notes: Guezouma Sanogo, journalist and president of the journalist association (AJB), was beaten up by a policeman while at the Peasant National Day in Kaya.
Gorane Dicko member of Ansaroul Islam and relative of Harouna Dicko - killed in March - was 'neutralised' by military forces.
A burkinabe vet was kidnapped by unidentified men in Forage Christine. He was later found the following day.
Workers walk down to the street to ask for an increase of salaries and purchasing power.

assoc_actor_1: UPC: Union for Progress and Reform; CDP: Congress for Democracy and Progress
notes: Nearly 5,000 supporters of the opposition, primarily UPC and CDP activists, gathred in Ouagadougou outside the People's House for a rally against the government.
An unidentified man was shot down at the entrance of the military camp of Fada-N'Gourma after he did not stop despite the security warnings.
Two Burkinabe state officers were kidnapped and released in the night.
2 Water Department workers were abducted by unidentified assailants in the Tin-Akoff area. They were later released.
Some traders demonstrated in front of the Palace of Justice against the detention of Inoussa Kanazoe, President-director general de CIMFASO.

assoc_actor_1: Mutiny of Police Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)
notes: A hundred former policemen, expelled from police forces after the 2011 mutiny, organised a sit-in to ask for their re-integration.
Angry protesters shut one of the main markets in Bobo-Dioulasso and marched to the governorates offices to submit a protest letter over poor roadways.

assoc_actor_1: UAS: Trade Union Action Unit; Students (Burkina Faso)
notes: 7 persons were wounded by police forces after police responded to the march of the UAS towards the town hall. Finally, the administrative document was declared void.
Students took hostage the mayor asking for the withdrawal of the administrative document.

assoc_actor_1: CCVC: National Coalition against High Cost of Living, Corruption, Fraud and Impunity and for Liberty
notes: People massively protested against the bad conditions of roads in the Eastern region.

About 200 police protested in Ouagadougou over the alleged lack of transparency over their provision of security to private companies.
44 people were arrested in the Pama and Nadiagou area after protests and arson attacks related to the shooting death of an alleged poacher in the area.
44 people were arrested in the Pama and Nadiagou area after protests and arson attacks related to the shooting death of an alleged poacher in the area.
Youth Coordination Bual Hamu blocked Road 4 Fada-Niger borders to ask for the road to be asphalted.
Residents of Douna staged a march in support of the mayor over alleged activity against him by local representatives of the CDP and the UPC.

assoc_actor_1: AFKK: Koglweogo Womens Association of Kouritenga; Women (Burkina Faso)
notes: The women's association Koglweogo Kouritenga protested against a court decision against some of their husbands related to some vigilante activities.

assoc_actor_1: SYNATEB: National Union of Basic Education Workers
notes: The SYNATEB affiliated gathered in front of the town hall for a sit-in asking the revision of a new document imposting heavier administrative burden on workers.
Kolgweogo in Pouytenga and surrounding areas gathered in Koupela to protest over the alleged condemnation of their comrades.
Security Measures: Burkinabe soldiers backed by Barkhane forces have started a large-scale search and clear operation in Soum province. Malian forces are also participating across the border.

Unidentified armed individuals on motorcycles raided the HQ of the Koglweogo in Kereboule, which they found empty. They then opened fire for nearly a quarter of an hour before leaving. At least one person was seriously injured during the firing.
A suspected Ansaroul Islam lieutenant was killed by security forces in the Petega area near Djibo. 18 other suspected militants were also arrested.
A youth organization (ODJ) organized a sit-in in Koudougou to protest against water shortages in the city.
Unidentified assailants attacked a joint-police/military camp in Nassoumbou. At least one soldier was wounded in a rocket attack, although gunfire was also reported.
The National Union of Tax Estate Agents started a strike and protested in the capital in favour of their demands.

actor1: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie
notes: A gendarme was injured in an attack by unidentified assailants in an ambush in the Petega area.
Koglweogo militiamen and an unidentified armed group clashed in the Kereboule area. No injuries reported.

assoc_actor_1: SYNAGRH: National Union of Human Resource Managers and Public Administration
notes: SYNAGRH members protested and started a 72-hour sit-in in Ouagadougou to demand attention to their grievances.

Property destruction: A school was burned down in the Baraboule area by suspected Islamist militants. Islamist groups, particularly Ansaroul Islam, have been targeting schools and teachers in the area recently.
Teachers marched in Ouagadougou and staged a sit-in in front of the Ministry of Education to protest against initimidation of teachers in Soum by suspected Islamist militants.
A school principal and another civilian were killed in an attack by suspected Ansaroul Islam fighters on a school in the Djibo area of Soum.

Non-violent activity: Schools in the Fourtenga commune of Nassere (Kongoussi) were visited by suspected Islamist militants who threatened to close them down if the teachers did not start teaching in Arabic.

Property destruction: Diguel was attacked by suspected Ansaroul Islam fighters in the early morning of Feb.28. They ransacked the mayors office, stole some property and burned down a prefecture building.
Ansaroul Islam fighters attacked 2 police stations in northern Burkina Faso at Baraboule and Tongomayel, injuring the wife of a police officer and destroying as many as 19 police motorcycles.
Ansaroul Islam fighters attacked 2 police stations in northern Burkina Faso at Baraboule and Tongomayel, injuring the wife of a police officer and destroying as many as 19 police motorcycles.
Youths, civil society members and traders blocked Coulibaly Avenue to protest the suspension of asphalting of the avenue.

Employees Safety Assistance Volunteers (VADS) personnel starting to demonstrate in front of the governorate building in Bobo-Dioulasso were quickly cleared by police who used tear gas and batons. A police spokesman said the protest was illegal. No injuries were reported.

assoc_actor_1: SYTTBHA: Workers Union of Public Works, Building, Water and Similar
notes: SYTTBHA workers protested and staged a sit-in in front of the Ministry of Infrastructure to demand resolution of their grievances.

assoc_actor_1: ONTTB: National Organisation of Burkinabe Land Carriers
notes: Truck drivers of the ONTTB protested and blocked the Ouaga-Kaya intersection to demand fewer road checks. They threatened to strike if nothing was done.

assoc_actor_1: SYNAFI: National Union of Finance Agents
notes: SYNAFI workers began an 11 day sit-in outside the ministry to demand their grievances be addressed.
A municipal councilor and his son were killed by unidentified assailants in the Yorsala area, near Titao.

assoc_actor_2: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie
notes: A crowd forced the release of 8 people imprisoned at a police station in Bagre. Following the events, clashes were reported between the rioters and police, which were later reinforced by gendarmerie forces. 37 people were arrested after the incident. No casualties were reported but some property was damaged.

Non-violent activity: Heavily armed Islamist militants were reported to have forced their way into schools in areas around Baraboule, including the Petega area of Pelem-Pelem and Lassa, and demanded teachers instruct their students on Islam and the Quran and stop teaching French. Burkinabe soldiers have been deployed to the area following the incidents.

Retired police and soldiers protested and staged a sit-in in front of the Ministry of Defence and Veteran's Affairs in Ouagadougou over the government's non-implementation of a shift in the retirement age.
Hundreds of people demonstrated in Bogande to demand the paving of the Taparko-Bogande-Fada road. Similar protests were held in Peila, Bilanga and Manni which are also along the same route.
Hundreds of people demonstrated in Bogande to demand the paving of the Taparko-Bogande-Fada road. Similar protests were held in Peila, Bilanga and Manni which are also along the same route.
Hundreds of people demonstrated in Bogande to demand the paving of the Taparko-Bogande-Fada road. Similar protests were held in Peila, Bilanga and Manni which are also along the same route.
Hundreds of people demonstrated in Bogande to demand the paving of the Taparko-Bogande-Fada road. Similar protests were held in Peila, Bilanga and Manni which are also along the same route.
Students in Santa blocked National Road No.7 to demand attention to their grievances.
1,500 people marched silently in Ouagadougou to mark the anniversary of the Hotel Splendid attack.

actor1: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie
notes: The Union of Lawyers of Burkina Faso (SYNAF) reported that a lawyer had been assaulted by police while he had been attempting to interview a defendant who had been in custody for more than 5 days.
One person was killed and another injured when Burkinabe soldiers fired warnings shots at approaching motorcycles in the Banh area of Loroum province.

Suspected Islamist fighters attacked the Kerboule mining site in Soum province, killing one Koglweogo member and 3 miners, injuring one other, and stealing 6 motorcycles and an unspecified sum of money. Islamist militias have been known to operate in the area.
Rallies were held against the continued use of the CFA in Burkina Faso.
An assassination was conducted in the Sibe area. The identity of the target was not reported. Ansaroul Islam claimed responsibility.
Non-violent activity: An assassination attempt was reported in the Djibo area. Ansaroul Islam claimed responsibility.
Members of an Al Qaeda affiliated group, Ansaroul Islam, killed an imam in a reprisal attack in the Tongomayel commune, in the village of Sibe. The imam had allegedly deserted the group.
Members of an Al Qaeda affiliated group, Ansaroul Islam, seriously injured anotther former member of the group in Djibo. The man was allegedly a deserter of the group.

assoc_actor_1: SYNAPAR: National Union of Research Support Staff
notes: SYNAPAR members staged a sit-in at the Institute of Environment and Agricultural Research in Ouagadougou to demand a sepcific allowance and expansion of a premium for their research.

Students and parents fought, resulting in several wounded, 15 motorcycles wrecked, and some damage to property, in a high school theatre in Niangoloko. The violence was related to a local school dispute.

At least 12 soldiers were killed in an attack by about 40 heavily armed gunmen on a Burkinabe military post on the border with Mali at Nassoumbou. An al-Qaeda-linked group calling itself Ansaroul Islam claimed the attack.
People of the Tangin Dassouri rural commune staged a peaceful march to demand that the authorities release Adam Zongo, a former mayor and former president of the FEDAP/BC.
Hundreds of demonstrators engaged in 13 minutes of silence and staged a sit-in outside the Ouagadougou courthouse to demand action over the death of an investigative journalist, Norbert Zongo.

Supporters of an MPP mayor of Ouagadougous 8th district staged violent protests after a vote of no confidence went against the mayor. The rioters ransacked and burned the homes of three councillors from the UPC and 2 from the MPP.

actor1: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie
notes: Gendarmerie from Koudougou shot dead a man "dressed all in white and turbaned" who refused police demands to stop as he was traveling towards their post.
Health workers marched on the second day of their 72-hour strike to demand better security for them at their workplaces.
100 youths marched in Banfora to protest against actions by some politicians to block the Banfora city council and dismiss the mayor.

assoc_actor_1: SYNTSHA: National Union of Human and Animal Health Workers
notes: Members of the National Union of Human and Animal Health (SYNTSHA), observed a sit-in on Nov. 16 and 17 at the regional hospital in Ouahigouya. The protesters demand the satisfaction of their platform of demands.

assoc_actor_1: SYNTSHA: National Union of Human and Animal Health Workers
notes: Members of the National Union of Human and Animal Health (SYNTSHA), observed a sit-in on Nov. 16 and 17 at the regional hospital in Ouahigouya. The protesters demand the satisfaction of their platform of demands.

A councilman of the village of Soboule, 30 kilometers from Nassoumbou, was wounded by unidentified armed man. While his gun jammed, the attacker was then lynched by the crowd, who then handed over to the defense and security forces.

Amadou Boli, the Imam preacher in sector 5 of Djibo and number 2 of Irshad (Network of preachers), was attacked at his home by armed men. While the motive under this murdr is unclear, a showdown seems to be behind this attack.

In Petega, 30 kilometers from Nassoumbou, Tamboura Amadou Oumarou, a village councilman, was murdered by four bullets in the head, and Dicko Hamadoum, a village resident, was kidnapped by the armed men.

A councilman of the village of Soboule, 30 kilometers from Nassoumbou, was wounded by unidentified armed man. While his gun jammed, the attacker was then lynched by the crowd, who then handed over to the defense and security forces.

assoc_actor_1: SYNATEB: National Union of Basic Education Workers; Teachers (Burkina Faso)
notes: Teachers of the National Union of Basic Education Workers section Bourzanga, observed a 48h work stoppage.

Several thousand people in the city of Yendabli took the street in tribute to the victims of the uprising population of 30 and 31 October 2014 and the failed coup of 16 September 2015 in Fada-NGourma.

assoc_actor_1: SYNATIC: Autonomous Syndicate of Information and Culture Workers
notes: The Independent Union of Workers of information and culture (Synatic) start 96 hours of general strike. The strikers decided to set up their picket outside the headquarters of the National Television of Burkina. But there, they were stopped by security forces deployed there.
The Minister of Internal Security claimed that a "jihadist recruiter" armed with a grenade was killed by security forces in the Kilwin neighbourhood of Ouagadougou.

About 8 heavily-armed unidentified assailants, believed to have crossed the border from Mali, attacked Kerboule village, in the Nassoumbou area. They killed 4 people and injured one before Kolgweogo self-defense militiamen from Boulsa arrived, causing the gunmen to retreat. The gunmen were allegedly speaking in Fulani.

About 8 heavily-armed unidentified assailants, believed to have crossed the border from Mali, attacked Kerboule village, in the Nassoumbou area. They killed 4 people and injured one before Kolgweogo self-defense militiamen from Boulsa arrived, causing the gunmen to retreat. The gunmen were allegedly speaking in Fulani.

source: Sidwaya; AP; Fasozine; Long War Journal
notes: 3 soldiers and 2 civilians were killed in an attack on a military position in Intangom, near Tin Akoff. 1 soldier was also wounded during the incident. The Islamic State in the Greater Sahara later claimed the attack. Another soldier later died of his injuries.

assoc_actor_1: SYNATRACT: National Union of Workers of the Local Authorities
notes: Staff of the regional authority engaged in a protest strike and demonstrated in front of the Ouagadougou Labour Exchange to demand attention to their grievances. The general secretary of SYNATRACT was in attendance.

actor1: Former Military Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)
notes: Non-violent activity: Burkina Fasos Minister of Territorial Administration, Decentralization and Homeland Security claims that a coup attempt was foiled on Oct.8 which had been organized by members of the disbanded Presidential Security Regiment. Members of the former regiment who did not participate allegedly informed the government about the plan.

actor1: Former Military Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)
actor2: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie
notes: 4 assailants accosted 2 gendarmes and attempted to steal their weapons near the Po gendarmerie station at Nazinon. 2 of the suspects were killed, while one of the attackers and a police officer were wounded. The government later claimed they were members of the disbanded Presidential Security Regiment.
Primary teachers of Boulgou province protested in Tankodogo to demand an education conference that was meant to be held in 2015 be held.

assoc_actor_1: CNSE: National Coordination of Education Unions; Teachers (Burkina Faso)
notes: The CNSE organized a protest march of sixteen teachers unions to commemorate World Teachers Day and deliver a memo to the Minister of Education.
Residents of the Soubeira area marched to Kaya to demand the involvement of the regional administrator in the resolution of a dispute in their area.
About 5,000 people demonstrated for the release of Djibril Bassole, a former Foreign Minister of President Campaores government, in his hometown of Reo. He was arrested in mid-September.
Workers of the National Blood Transfusion Centre held a 48-hour sit-in outside the premises of the centre in Ouagadougou to demand the implementation of a rebate to the centres workers.
Former workers of Bissa Gold staged a sit-in to demand their unpaid severance following their October 2015 dismissals.
SYNATEL began a strike and sit-in at ONATEL to demand resolution of their grievances.

assoc_actor_1: SYNTSHA: National Union of Human and Animal Health Workers
notes: SYNTSHA workers began a 4-day, 4-hour work stoppage at the Yalgado-Ouedraogo hospital along with sit-ins to draw attention to their grievances.
Arrests: Burkina Fasos former PM under the government of President Blaise Compaore, Luc-Adolphe Tiao, was arrested on charges of murder.
The civil registry of Sabse department was burned down by demonstrators demanding the dissolution of a newly-installed city council in the area.

2 customs officials (including a border guard) were killed in an attack on the border town of Markoye. 3 people were also wounded. The assailants stole customs money and fled to the Nigerien border. The leader of the Islamic States Sahara division claimed responsibility for the attack.

assoc_actor_1: SYNATIC: Autonomous Syndicate of Information and Culture Workers
notes: SYNATIC workers staged a sit-in to demand attention to their grievances.
A vigilante militant killed a rider in Yonde.

assoc_actor_1: CDAIP: Coordination of Defense Committees and Deepening the Gains of the Popular Uprising
notes: Nearly 300 traders in the 3rd quarter of Ouagadougou held a sit-in and "faced off" with police who were ordered to "interrupt" the protest. Eventually, the mayor agreed to receive leaders for negotiations.
Strikes: Toll workers went on a 72 hour strike nationwide, demanding better working conditions and re-privatization.
Zongho residents protested the recent arrest of vigilantes, blocking national route 1. Authorities tried to negotiate and then used tear gas to disperse them.

assoc_actor_1: Former Military Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014)
actor2: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie
notes: 100 former soldiers who took part in the 2011 attempted coup protested in front of the Ministry of Defense, demanding reinstatement in the military. Gendarmes blocked them from reaching the Ministry.

On 24 June 2016, locals armed with clubs, knives and machetes fought with a communal armed group in a suburb of Ouagadougou (Kadiogo, Centre) who attempted to arrest a thief. Five injured and several vigilantes later arrested. [size=no report]
Mineral transporters protested regarding tariffs.
After a disputed mayoral election, opposing political groups clashed, causing several injuries.

assoc_actor_2: Fulani Ethnic Group (Burkina Faso); Government of Burkina Faso (2015-)
notes: Political opponents attacked and injured the newly elected mayor from the Fulani ethnic group, setting his home on fire.
Two killed and at least 30 wounded in clashes between political opponents after contested mayoral election.
Political opponents attacked the newly elected mayor, who was hospitalized for his injuries.
Disputes over local chief led to clashes, one killed.
After a disputed mayoral election, opposing political groups clashed. One MPP activist killed and around a dozen injured.
About 20 relatives of detainees protested outside a prison, demanding their loved ones receive speedy trials and be released in accordance with their sentences.
Hundreds of protesters with clubs and machetes blocked the Ouagadougou-Dori road, demanding the MPP candidate be named mayor.
Workers from the Ministry of Women, National Solidarity, and Family held a sit in to denounce outsider appointments.
Bakers went on strike. Dozens protested in front of the Ministry of Public Service to demand better living and working conditions.

assoc_actor_1: CNOSC: Consultation Framework for Civil Society Organizations
notes: 100 activists protested against bail for various members of the former regime suspected of involvement in reprisals against civilians in October 2014 and in September 2015.
"Jihadists" on motorbikes attacked a police station 5km from the border with Mali, killing three and stealing weapons.
Tollbooth workers launched a three-day nationwide sit-in.
Four political parties joined to march to protest cancelled municipal elections.
MPP activists tried to stop NTD supporters from voting. Police intervened. No reports of violence
Armed men attacked police station, injuring two. Attackers may be "jihadists from Mali."
Angry residents ransacked local offices of the National Independent Electoral Commission (CENI) ahead of municipal elections.
Young entrepreneurs held a sit-in outside the Prime Ministers office to demand funding.

Angry residents ransacked local offices of the National Independent Electoral Commission (CENI) ahead of municipal elections.
Four men attacked police station at Loropeni, the attackers are speculated to be "jihadists from Mali".

Angry mob burned a car that allegedly killed a motorcyclist.

Students rioted, tearing the flag, burning property, and attacking teachers.
Vigilantes beat and whipped two suspected thiefs, demanding they pay a fine before letting them go.

actor1: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-2015) Presidential Security Unit

notes: Non-violent activity: The Presidential Security Unit took hostage Prime Minister Zida, President Kafando, and two ministers and set up barricades around the presidential palace. They named themselves the National Council for Democracy and declared General Gilbert Diendere their leader. The closed land and air borders for 24 hours and put a curfew in effect.

Coup/Military takeover: President Compaore steps down as president. General Traore assumes position as acting Head of State (replaced by Gen. Zida on Nov. 1), creates a transitional government body for next 12 months, and announces elections will take place within 90 days.

Tens of thousands of protesters gather in front of the National Assembly on Friday morning demanding Compaores resignation and calling for former defense minister Kouame Lougue to take power. Leader of opposition Zephyrinus Diabre urges crowds to maintain pressure by occupying public space.
Looting of industrial and financial institutions in Bobo-Dioulasso.

source: BBC News; Deutsche Welle; Guardian (Nigeria); Le Pays; AP; AFP
notes: Tens of thousands rioted and burned the Assemblee Nationale du Burkina Faso, and set fire to cars outside. Rioters wanted to stop parliament from voting on a constitutional amendment to the presidential two-term limit. President Compaore declares state of emergency; cancels the declaration a few hours later. Reports of 30 dead and 100 wounded. Later reports clarify a total of 24 deaths, around 650 wounded, and 265 infringements during the uprising.

Riots throughout Ouagadougou; looting, burning homes of government officials, including mayor of Ouagadougou, Marin Casimir Ilbouda. One rioter killed by the police while attacking the home of President Comparoes brother, Francois Compaore.

Students and University staff protested the closing of the main university.
After police arrested students planning to protest for the following day, protests were still held. Police dispersed people who showed up for the protest.
Students protested and police responded by throwing teargas at protesters.
Student rioters demanding more grants erected barricades and set a car on fire. Police responded to the riots with teargas.
Students rioted to demand grants. Rioters set a car on fire and erected barricades. Police responded by firing teargas into the crowd.
Protesters demonstrated against government corruption.
Protesters demonstrated for an end to government abuses and an investigation into Norbert Zongos death.

Rioters demonstrated against the way Norbert Zongos murder trial was being handled. Rioters set up barricades of burning tires and threw stones at police. Police responded by throwing teargas at rioters.
Rioters demanding more investigations into the death of Norbert Zongo clashed with police. Rioters burned tires and pelted stones at police while police fired teargas at rioters.
Rioters protested for authorities to look further into Norbert Zongos death. Rioters threw stones at police cars. Police intervened in the riots.

actor1: UNEF: National Union of Faso Students
notes: Members of the National Union of Faso Students (UNEF) attacked students who belonged to the National Association of Burkinabe Students (ANEB) who were attending class despite a call to protest.
Protesters demonstrated for a transparent investigation for the murder of Norbert Zongo, an outspoken journalist. Zongo was killed on 13-December-1998.
Protesters demonstrated over the 1998 murder of Norbert Zongo.

Students protested for the release of other students previously jailed. Police responded by firing teargas at the protesters.
Riots broke out in Banfora after a police officer shot a man in custody. Rioters ransacked the police station. Soldiers responded to the rioters and imposed a curfew on the town.
After a policeman shot a mechanic, citizens responded by burning and ransacking the police station. A curfew was imposed in the town by military officers to try and keep peace in the town.
Soldiers protested peacefully to demand a wage increase.
Civil servant workers protested low wages and human rights abuses by the government. The day was chosen for protesting since it was the second day of a five day conference of Islamic countries.
